content: Actually the entire message pane is expanded to the length of the attachment filename. So if the message window is narrower than the filename, all elements of the message pane justified to the right (scroll bars, buttons, etc) are pushed off the window and not accessible. The window with the message pane must be widened until the filename is fully displayed.
creator: johned0420

content: Try view>Fontsize to change the size of message list. The fonts in settings>general are saved everytime you make changes.

content:
Did you originaly mean to ask a question about how to go back to an earlier version ? Because I'm not sure what your question is supposed to be about!

You paid someone to uninstall new and reinstall old.

In future if anyone finds this question and does not want to pay to downgrade then try this:

In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Under 'Application Basics' half way - Profile Folder - click on 'Open Folder' (if Windows OS) or 'Open Finder' (if a MAC)

A new window opens showing the contents of your 'profile name folder'

Exit Thunderbird now

delete this file: 'compatibility.ini'

Uninstall Thunderbird


Get a fresh download from this link: Last version before update to 115* was 102.15.1 http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/

If windows select eg: 'win64/' if MAC select 'mac/' then choose prefered language eg: en-GB is English British Then download the .exe file if Windows OS or the .dmg file if MAC Install and run and it will pick up your profile.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: If your friends are reporting mail undeliverable, that is an issue between their computer and your email server, not your PC. I encourage you to pursue with your email provider.

content:
I'm not having the problem with threaded view auto enabled, I just get a list of any emails which were in the thread, so unthreaded list. But the one I selected to see is not highlighted so basically I have no idea which one I selected. All the From is the same and so is all the subject, so like you I have to recheck the date and sometimes time as well of the one I selected. It's just a painful process which did not occur in 102.15.1

Either way - I would expect:

  1. Unthreaded list
  2. Email I clicked on to be highlighted
  3. Email I clicked on to auto open and display contents below.

I've just created a bug on this issue.

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1860815


Do you have the auto threaded view switched off ? I have done the following and do not have a problem in the search results window. See if it helps you.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Config Editor' button - It opens in a new tab
  • In search type: default_view
  • You will see this line: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 1
  • click on the 'pencil' icon on the right to allow an edit.
  • Remove the number 1 and type in a zero 0
  • click on the 'tick' icon to save your settings.

You will now have: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 0 This will now mean any new folders you create, they will not have threading by default.

See if setting this preference helps to stop the threading in search result.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: In a previous question, you stated the affected account is an IMAP account. If that is the case, right-click the account and select Subscribe. The dialog that opens should show all your IMAP mailbox folders, including the Deleted folder. Simply make sure to place a tick next to the folder to subscribe to it. Quit and restart Thunderbird, and the Deleted folder should be in the Folder Pane as before.

content: This should do it: - exit thunderbird - copy the desired local folders to the other drive - start thunderbird - click to 'account settings' and scroll to Local Folders - click the Browse button at 'local directory' and change to the new location - now you can delete from the Mail\Local Folders folder

content:
So, directly edit the message in-place. Well, the only thing that comes close is this add-on https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-GB/thunderbird/addon/header-tools-improved/

If the intention is to keep the message in the mailbox, with full content including the attachment, then why bother to edit it in the first place? So, you're editing this message to include storage location information for where its attachments were saved locally, but the edited message itself still contains this attachment. It just doesn't make any sense.
creator: stancestans

content: After modification of this email there is no need to remove, it is just the opposite, the objective is, to keep the modified email in your email-box. You want to keep the full content, the attachment is still available (but outside of the email-box) and also the email itself.
creator: stefan169

content: So, you want to keep the modified email in your mailbox, minus the attachment (stored externally), and delete the original email to reduce your email server storage quota usage?
creator: stancestans

content:
Thanks for your kind reply :-)

Ok, maybe the link above is misleading ...

Here a new attempt to make it clear what I would like to achieve:

One use case is: You receive regularly email with attachment, you have four options:

  • keep them as is (that transform your email-box into a file storage, this might be inconvenient)
  • forward the email to yourself, save the attachment in an appropriate directory, add a note where the attachment is stored, afterwards delete the original email (bad workaround)
  • modify the email (save the attachment outside of your email-box, add information about the file location)

In outlook you have two options to achieve the third option:

  • install an add-on or code something in VBA
  • edit the email and save the modified email (without attachment but with the information included about the file location of the original attachment)

Another use case might be, you would like to just correct something in an email, e.g. an internet-link that is outdated

Now I wonder how this can be achieved in Thunderbird, the option "edit as new" is not suitable for my purpose.
creator: stefan169

content:
Method 1

Right-click the message > Save As > HTML Files > Save.

Right-click the saved HTML file > Open With > Word

There is, unfortunately, no option in Thunderbird to do the above on the fly.

Method 2

Right-click the message > Edit as New Message

Edit as needed

File menu > Save As > File.

When done, simply close the editor. If a copy of the edited message is automatically saved in the Drafts folder, just delete it from there and you're done.
creator: stancestans

content:
The 'Probate' folder has got the icon associated with 'Drafts'. So it seems Thunderbird thinks 'Probate' is your Drafts folder.

'In 'Account Settings' > 'Copies & folders' for that mail account Under 'Drafts & Templates' section keep draft messages in: If it is a pop mail account:

  • select 'Drafts folder on' and select the pop account.

If it is an imap account:

  • select 'Other' and choose 'Drafts on imap account'

content:
I figured it out.

Yay TextEdit. Almost as good as ResEdit. ;-)

In the Profile folder: Compatibility.ini has a version line. prefs.js has the app version noted three times. prefs.js also has a line "lastAppBuildId"

I changed the content on those lines, in my preferred, but not working profile, to content on those same lines from a new, empty profile created in 102. Launched Thunderbird 102, and it loaded my default profile without issue.

See also: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles To properly set your old profile as the default.

TYVM.
creator: VidPro
